Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Story: I noticed my wife sitting quietly at the kitchen table, her brow furrowed, fingers tracing circles on her mug. I remembered our promise to always talk things through, to share our worries instead of bottling them up. I sat down beside her, ready to ask what was on her mind, to listen and be there for her. Just as I opened my mouth, my phone buzzed. It was a message from Mark, my old college friend. “Hey, man, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m drowning in these IKEA instructions and could really use your help.” I glanced at my wife, who looked up at me with tired eyes, and then at my phone, Mark’s message blinking on the screen. I felt torn—my wife needed me to be present, to listen, to communicate like we promised. But Mark rarely asks for help, and I knew he was counting on me to be there for him, especially now. My heart pounded as I sat between the two worlds, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which way to turn.
